title: 111_s1242
content: The "Government Ownership Exit Plan Act of 2009" defines ownership interest as troubled assets purchased by the Secretary under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. The Act focuses on the re-privatization of private entities. The "Government Ownership Exit Plan Act of 2009" prohibits the Federal Government from acquiring any ownership interests and requires divestiture by July 1, 2010. The Secretary may hold ownership interests for up to 6 months with limited authority under certain conditions. The "Government Ownership Exit Plan Act of 2009" prohibits Federal Government ownership interests, allowing a 6-month extension under specific conditions. A single renewal for up to 6 months is possible if certain criteria are met, with a conforming amendment to the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008, specifically regarding the deposit of funds into the treasury and the removal of certain provisions. The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 is amended to deposit funds into the treasury for debt reduction and remove certain provisions. Management decisions' influence is also addressed in the Act. Management decisions' influence is addressed in the Act, specifically in Section 137. The Act defines 'covered person' as an executive branch officer or employee and 'significant management decision' includes key business choices. It prohibits covered persons from influencing such decisions. The Act prohibits covered persons from influencing significant management decisions of recipients of assistance. Violating this rule can result in a criminal penalty of a fine, imprisonment, or both. The Attorney General can also enforce this rule through civil actions, with violators facing a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation. The Attorney General can petition a court to prohibit a covered person from engaging in conduct that violates the Act. This does not prevent other legal remedies available to the United States or any other person. The Act allows the Attorney General to seek court intervention to stop violations, without limiting other legal remedies available to the United States or any person. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's ability to maintain banking system stability is not affected by the Act. SEC. 4. Oversight by Financial Stability Oversight Board, amending Section 104(a) of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 to include reviewing the implementation of the Government Ownership Exit Plan Act of 2009. SEC. 5. Reports required. The Secretary must provide periodic reports on Federal Government ownership interests, including loans and guarantees, with deadlines for submission. Additionally, reports on plans for compliance with the Act, including divestment strategies, must be submitted to Congress. The Secretary must provide periodic reports on Federal Government ownership interests, with deadlines for submission, including monthly reports until all ownership interests are divested. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 90 days outlining a plan to end the conservatorship and eliminate direct ownership by the Federal Government of the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
